SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-25 Ordering an Election to Authorize the Issuance of School Bonds, Establishing Specifications of the Election Order, and Requesting Consolidation with Other Elections Occurring on November 4, 2014   
		 
The proposed Resolution #2013/2014-25 authorizes a bond measure to be placed on the ballot for the general election to be held on November 4, 2014, authorizing the issuance of General Obligation Bonds of the District for the purpose of financing designated technology projects of the District.  The Bonds will be authorized under the provisions of Proposition 39, which requires approval of 55% or more of the voters.  The Resolution specifies the principal amount of the Bonds, which will be determined by the Board at the meeting, as well as the term of the Bonds and other specifics of the ballot measure.  Appendix A to the Resolution includes the list of specific projects for which the Bonds are authorized.  In order to place the bond measure on the ballot, the proposed Resolution must be adopted by at least 2/3 of the Board members.  Under the Education Code Section 15264, the adopted Resolution must be delivered to the County at least 88 days prior to the election date.
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
If authorized, the Bonds are payable from ad valorem property taxes levied on taxpayers in the District.  The County will apportion the costs of running the election among all of the agencies which have measures on the ballot, which must be paid whether or not the Bonds are authorized.
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Costs of the election are payable from the General Fund of the District, although such costs may be reimbursed from Bond proceeds if the election is successful.
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the proposed Resolution #2013/2014-25 Ordering an Election to Authorize the Issuance of School Bonds, Establishing Specifications of the Election Order, and Requesting Consolidation with Other Elections Occurring on November 4, 2014.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Proposition 39 Facilities MOU with Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter High School
		 
On October 28, 2013, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2014-2015 school year from Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter High School (“LVLA”) (then known as “Latino College Preparatory Academy II”).  The District timely responded to the request per the requirement of the Education Code and the Code of Regulations.  At the March 20, 2014, Board meeting, the Board of Trustees authorized Administration’s request to deny LVLA’s Proposition 39 Facilities request.  
		 
Administration has been in continuing contact and discussion with LVLA.  LVLA has been actively recruiting Administration and staff for its charter school and students.
		 
In light of these new developments, Administration recommends entering into a one year facility MOU to provide LVLA charter school facilities at Yerba Buena High School pursuant to the District’s standard form MOU and subject to LVLA paying its pro rata share for such facilities consistent with other charter schools occupying other district facilities.

It is recommended for the reasons stated above, that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to enter into the Facilities MOU with LVLA as presented.

BACKGROUND
	 
The Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School petition was submitted to the Board on April 17, 2014. Pursuant to Education Code 47605, a public hearing is required within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition to the board and a decision on authorization within 60 days unless an extension is agreed upon by both parties.  The public hearing will be held on May 15, 2014. Both parties have agreed to an extension on the decision for authorization. The decision will be made during the June 19, 2014, Board Meeting. 
	 
The purpose of the public hearing is for the Governing Board of the school district to consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents. 
	 
Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School proposes to open in the Alum Rock community in 2015 with 175 ninth grade students. At full capacity (approximately 175 students will be added each year), the school will serve approximately 600 students. The petitioners currently operate Alpha: Blanca Alvarado Middle School, grades six through eight, which opened in the Alum Rock Union School District in fall 2012. The petitioners are seeking to extend this model through high school as delineated in the Alpha: Cindy Avitia High School petition.

PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Julie Kasberger, Director of General Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Changes to the Food Service Program
		 
		 
The District’s Food Service Program has been under considerable financial pressure over the last 2-3 years in relation to increased State and Federal mandates, which has resulted in the District expending additional fiscal resources with no additional revenues in return. In addition, the District’s last increase in breakfast and lunch pricing last occurred in 2008-09, at $.25 for breakfast and $.25 lunch. The cost of operating the District’s Food Service Program has outpaced the amount of revenues available and has resulted in a number of program challenges.    
		 
The changes proposed to the Food Service Program at East Side Union High School District are being recommended to address these challenges.  In the fiscal year ending 2012-13, the Program lost $213,000 and is projected to lose another $179,000 by the end of the current fiscal year ending June 30, 2014.  At the end of the current fiscal year, the food service reserve fund is expected to have a balance of $181,000 and is expected to be fully depleted by June 30, 2015, if no action is taken.  If the food service reserve fund becomes fully depleted, the Program will have to be supplemented by the District’s general fund if losses continue.  This situation is commonly referred to as encroachment and will result in less money being available to support sites, staffing and academic programs.       
		 
The District is offering the following three recommendations in order to address this situation:  
		 
Recommendation #1 – Implement a meal price increase:
Effective July 1 - Fiscal Year 2014-15
Paid Breakfast – Increase by $.25 from $1.50 to $1.75
Paid Lunch – Remain the same at $3.00
Paid Adult Lunch – Increase by $.25 from $3.50 to $3.75
In comparison to eight local districts surveyed, East Side ranks the lowest in breakfast pricing and it was also determined that our current free and reduced pricing is actually supporting the Paid Breakfast pricing.  This is a situation that definitely should not occur and is actually in violation of the National School Lunch Act if this had been the case with the District’s lunch program.  As a result, the District is recommending a $.25 increase to Paid Breakfast pricing.  In regard to the student lunch program, East Side’s pricing is on average with the comparison group of school districts.  As a side note, East Side’s pricing is $.25 less than San Jose Unified School District.  The District is not recommending any increase in student lunch pricing at this time.  The District is recommending a $.25 increase to Paid Adult Lunches.  The District’s Paid Adult Lunch pricing ranks at the bottom of the survey group.  It is estimated that the proposed changes to Paid Breakfast and Adult Lunch pricing will result in an increase of $7,436 in ongoing revenue.   
		 
Recommendation #2 – Eliminate charging for Reduced Price Meals:
Federal eligibility requirements for reduced price lunch are the same in San Jose, California as it is in Bismark, North Dakota; however, the costs of living in San Jose is 50% higher.  We don’t believe this situation is equitable or fair to the students and parents who are eligible for reduced priced meals at East Side Union High School District.  There have been several other Northern California school districts which have taken this same position to eliminate reduced pricing, which are Morgan Hill Unified and Sacramento City Unified.  East Side would be the largest district in the Bay Area to take this position on behalf of lower income parents and students.  The current eligibility criteria for reduced priced meal is as follows:

The District currently has 2,954 approved applications on file for reduced priced eligible students.  The current pricing for reduced priced breakfast is $.30 and $.40 for lunch.  The District estimates that it will cost $130,914 to cover the lost revenue.  The National School Lunch Program funding is not allowed to cover the reduced price revenue loss – the loss revenue must be paid from another source and we plan to utilize vending revenue to cover the shortfall.  
		 
Rationale to Support this Recommendation 
Based on our research and information from districts which have already eliminated reduced pricing, they have experienced exponential increases in breakfast and lunch participation. It was reported in a local Sacramento Newspaper that “A local district experiencing budget cuts re-imposed reduced price charges after years of not charging students for reduced price meals. The district found after a year's trial that fewer students were eating breakfast and lunch and that total revenues decreased. The following year, the reduced price charges were eliminated and they had a noticeable increase in participation and total revenue increased”. (Rosemont, CA Patch, May 7, 2013)
		 
The District believes that, if reduced pricing is eliminated, overall free breakfast and lunch participation will increase at the same % of current free lunch participation Districtwide. Current free breakfast and lunch program participation are at 25.8% and 38.8%, respectively.   The District projects that the increased participation for reduced price elimination would result in increased (State & Federal) reimbursements totaling $129,622 for breakfast and $207,969 for lunch.  The increase in reimbursement revenues is projected to total $337,591.  The total projected net revenue gain to the District is $206,677 ($337,591 - $130,914).   
		 
The District believes this approach is a game changer in regard to our approach in delivering our program to lower income families.  We believe this is truly a "win, win, win" for our students, parents and the District and will enable East Side to not only meet the needs of lower income families, but to also increase participation and bolster revenues.    
		 
Recommendation #3 – Implement  an After-School Supper Program:
Currently, the District’s Child Nutrition Program supports seven after school programs throughout the District as part of the National School Lunch Program (NSLP).  The NSLP program allows the District to provide an after school snack to District eligible students consisting of pretzels and orange juice, muffin and milk, or graham crackers and milk.  In return for providing the snacks to eligible students, the NSLP provides a reimbursement to the District.  For fiscal year 2013-14, the reimbursement amount is estimated at $205,800.  In fiscal year 2014-15, the District is planning to increase the number of after school programs offered, such as Gear Up, California Community Partners for Youth (CCPY), and Goodwill.  It is anticipated that hundreds of more students will participate in these very vital programs.  
		 
The District is requesting the Board’s consideration to replace the snack program with a Supper Program, which is sponsored by the Child and Adult Care Food Program (CACFP), and will provide students with a full supper, including a meat/meat alternative, grain, fruit, vegetable, and milk.  The Program provides a higher District reimbursement and allows sites with 50% or more free and reduced eligible students to offer meals for free to all students, regardless of their meal status.  The program does not require students to show ID and would be available to all students participating in after-school programs.      
		 
In order to support this initiative, the District would need to hire at least 16 new 4.75 FTEs.  The District is projecting to be reimbursed for at least 1,815 meals per day, which would generate a total reimbursable income of $860,991 under the CACFP.  The projected cost for the increased meals and labor costs would total an estimated $556,305.  The increase in reimbursement revenues is projected to total $304,686.  The total projected net revenue gain to the District is $98,886 ($304,686 - $205,800).

All recommendations are self-funded and do not require earmarked funds from the general fund or the Child Nutrition Service Fund (Fund 61).

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Award a Lease/Lease Back Pre-Construction Agreement for Independence High School Performing Arts Center – Building F Modernization
	 
Background
On February 14, 2013 (Item 8.07), the Board of Trustees received a presentation on Alternative Public Works Construction Delivery Methods.   On October 17, 2013 (Item 15.01), the Board received a presentation on utilizing the Lease/Leaseback Delivery Method for Modernization Projects at Independence High School.  Staff continued to analyze the benefits of using the Lease/Leaseback Delivery method for the Modernization Projects at Independence High School and proceeded with the development based on the rational that this delivery method is ideal for complex projects with multiple scopes. This method would provide fewer change orders due to a pre-construction agreement, greater price certainty as the contractor offers a guaranteed maximum price (GMP), team collaboration to identify a fair scope within the budget and early involvement of contractor adds construction practicality to design imagination are some of the reasons staff determined this was the proper method to use.
	 
Development of Lease/Leaseback Request for Qualifications and Proposals (RFQ/P)
The Request for Qualifications and Proposals (RFQ/P) was developed by Facilities and Capital Purchasing staff, in conjunction with the construction manager for the project, Van Pelt Construction Services. The RFQ/P was seeking Lease/Leaseback Developers who are experienced in the construction of public school facilities in Northern California, and are experienced with the lease/leaseback method of project delivery to provide to the District pre-construction services, project cost estimates, design constructability review, value engineering and construction services.
	 
The RFQ/P specified that the following selection criteria were to be considered in determining best value and selecting the most qualified LLB whose proposal provides comprehensive pre-construction and construction services at a competitive price with the highest quality:

 10 points

   5 points

 30 points

 20 points

Use of Local Subcontractors
  5 points

 15 points
Total (Maximum)
100 points
                                   
Issuance of Request for Proposals
The RFQ/P (RFQ/P-15-13-14) was issued on March 11, 2014, to the District’s Prequalified Contractors as well as plan rooms, and posted on the District’s website, pursuant to the Authority of Education Code §17406. A mandatory Pre-Submittal Conference was held on March 18, 2014.  Eleven Developers and one Subcontractor attended the Pre-Submittal Conference.
	 
Receipt of Proposals from Lease Leaseback Developers
On April 7, 2014, the District received seven Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) from McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., Blach Construction Company, Turner Construction Company, Jeff Luchetti Construction Company, Alten Construction Company, XL Construction, and Overaa Construction.
	 
Proposal Evaluation Process
All submitted proposals underwent an in-depth technical review by construction management staff. The purpose of this review was to score each Developer’s proposal based on the criteria outlined in the RFQ/P. Capital Purchasing and Facilities staff reviewed and accepted the evaluation scores.  The intent was to invite the top three scoring Developers to interview. All Developers that submitted SOQs were well qualified; four SOQs were most responsive to the RFQ/P:  Turner Construction Company, XL Construction, Overaa Construction and McCarthy Building Companies, Inc.  The third place score was tied, so staff elected to interview four teams in lieu of allowing the tie to prejudice either Developer.  The top four teams each scored 87% or higher. 
	 
Interview Process
The four highest scoring Developers from the proposal review process were invited to interview on April 14, 2014.  On that day, each Developer was given a 45-minute time slot.  15 minutes were allotted for an initial presentation, then 30 minutes for questions/answers. The interview panel was comprised of the Independence High School Principal, Capital Purchasing and Facilities Planning staff, Van Pelt Construction Services construction management team, and the project Architect of Record staff.
	 
Conclusions and Next Steps
The panel deliberated extensively after the interviews.  While the panel was impressed with each of the four Developers, and commented that any one of them could provide excellent delivery of this project, the panel ranked the teams as follows:

SUBJECT:
Approve Permanent Course Adoption for Digital Photo 1, Ethnic Studies,  and Technical Theater 1-4
	 
	 
The Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed Digital Photo 1, Ethnic Studies, and Technical Theater 1-4.  These courses was piloted during the 2013-2014 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.
	 
Digital Photo 1
	 
Digital Photo 1 is a year introductory level Visual Arts course.  Students, grades 9th -12th, will have the opportunity to study the elements and principles of art as they apply to digital photographic images.  Students will study the history of photography to the current technological age while learning composition, and various photographic techniques in a lab environment.  Students will be creating photographs using digital cameras, computer photo editing software, scanning, uploading, downloading, importing, and printing said images.  Students will look at the formal, expressive and aesthetic properties of photographic art. 
	 
Ethnic Studies
The Ethnic Studies course aims to educate students to be politically, socially, and economically conscious about their personal connections to local and global histories.  By studying the histories of race, ethnicity, nationality, and culture, students will cultivate respect and empathy for individuals and solidarity with groups of people locally, nationally, and globally so as to foster active social engagement and community building.  Honoring the historical legacy of social movements and mass struggle against injustice, including the establishment of ethnic studies programs in public schools and university curricula, this course aims to provide an emancipatory education that will inspire students to critically engage in self-determination and seek social justice of all.
	 
Technical Theater 1-4
Students learn the skills of theater sound, lighting and design.  Students receive hands on instruction on 
the operation and maintenance of all theatrical equipment.

DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
